clinical_study.brief_title: Deliberate Ultraviolet Light Exposure to Get a Tan by Young Adult Sexual Minority Males
clinical_study.official_title: Analysis of Tanning Attitudes and Behaviors by Young Adult Sexual Minority Males in the Greater Chicago Area

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to: a) identify enablers and barriers to deliberate ultraviolet light exposure by young sexual minority men (SMM), and b) quantify the extent of their deliberate ultraviolet light exposure.

detailed_description.textblock:
Aim 1: To develop survey items to assess tanning attitudes and behaviors Nine survey items used by the PI in previous deliberate tanning research were adapted with the expert consensus of members of Northwestern's Institute for Sexual and Gender Minority Health and Wellbeing. Discussions with the PI, research personnel and members of the institute developed the hypothesis that in addition to the previously reported appearance motivations young SMM may be engaging in tanning (indoors or outdoors) as a social activity. A tenth survey item was developed to assess deliberate tanning as a social activity.
Aim 2: Analyze the tanning attitudes and behavior data acquired in an online survey of young adult sexual minority males, who regularly participate in the RADAR study.
RADAR is a longitudinal study with cohorts from the greater Chicago region recruited between 2008 and 2015. The 10 survey items about tanning attitudes and behaviors were added to the online survey that examines SMMs' behavior in the prior 6 months. This is a secondary analysis of registry data acquired by the RADAR study.

primary_outcome.description: For test-retest reliability of the 10 items, 50 participants would allow a two-category kappa to be estimated to within Â±0.15 using 95% confidence intervals assuming that Cronbach's alpha values were 0.6 or higher.

The demographic characteristics of the population will be compared for never purposely tan vs ever purposely tan with chi square tests. The primary analysis will be analysis of variance (ANOVA) for the mean Likert scale values of the 10 self-reported survey items. Multiple logistic regression will be used to determine the odds ratio (OR) and independence of predictors of deliberate ultraviolet light exposure to get a tan.

intervention.description: This is a secondary analysis of registry data.

study_pop.textblock: RADAR is a longitudinal study with cohorts from the greater Chicago region recruited between 2008 and 2015. Participants respond to online surveys every 6 months.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Young adult SMM (age 18-39)
- Able to read English
- Have internet access
- Willing to complete the online survey
Exclusion Criteria:
- None

eligibility.gender_description: Participants self-identify as sexual minority males

facility.name: Northwestern University Feinberg School of Medicine Department of Dermatology

patient_data.ipd_description: Since all data is deidentified, the results cannot be shared individually; however, the results may be provided to the entire cohort in a newsletter.

study_doc.doc_comment: Mustanski, Brian. Multilevel Influences on HIV and Substance Use in a YMSM Cohort (RADAR) - Visit #1, Chicago Metropolitan Area, 2015-2018. Inter-university Consortium for Political and Social Research [distributor], 2020-03-19.

provided_document.document_type: Study Protocol and Statistical Analysis Plan
